I read* that water is not a good conductor as, for example, metals, so when you heat the water from the top, it doesn't transfer heat to the bottom as much and also it doesn't circulate as much because the heated water already at the top (buoyancy force won't push heated water to the top because it is already at the top). Fluids evaporate all the time and the more heated the water the faster it evaporates, also when you boil water It loses air (the bubbles you see) that was dissolved in it and when you boil it from the top the air doesn't need to go from bottom to the top in form of air bubbles, so the water remains still**. *in my physics book "Физика 8 класс Перышкин Дрофа" page 54.
If you heat it, it tends to go higher. At the top, it's already at the highest, and colder water cannot rise.

Heat and thermal energy aren't the same thing. Heat is transfer of thermal energy. It's the thermodynamic version of work.

Rhaegar19 in the scientific community, heat has always been deemed an inaccurate term because of the same thing u have pointed out - people can define it has a transfer of thermal energy (University texts tend to avoid using the word heat) or as heat energy (which is grossly inaccurate). This creates confusion in the scientific community, and precisely because of its level of ambiguity both as a noun and a verb (you choose to define it as a verb, but there are people out there who choose to use it as a noun).   Btw, there is no such thing as "thermodynamic version of work". It is simply thermal energy, because energy = work done. Work is work, regardless of it being gravitational potential, electric or mechanical. Strictly speaking, there is no need to even pinpoint a it as a "version" of work.

I think there's definitely a need to distinguish between total energy and change of energy in a system. Both terms come up in the same equation pretty frequently.   I don't see how "heat" is any more ambiguous than "work" or "mass" or "momentum". A lot of scientific terms have had their meanings corrupted by popular culture, so it's just important to precisely define your terms before you begin. By the way, I defined "heat" as a noun, not a verb.  If you look at a system on the molecular level, heat is the same thing as work, but if you're talking about macroscopic objects they're not even close to describing the same thing. It's the same reason we don't use Maxwell's equations to do basic chemistry.

The temperature stays during the phase changes at 0 and 100. At 20 and 60 the water isn't changing phases and the temperature is increasing. You can tell the difference, 60 is hot. The graph shows this by continuing the increasing slope during this section.

I think that would be the second law. Thats going to be the next video, looking at the end cards of this video. The second law of thermodynamics is "entropy does not decrease in isolated systems". Where entropy is (sort of) a measure of how spread out the energy in a system is, and isolated systems are systems that don't interact with anything outside of them (like the universe as a whole). So basically it says that if energy changes configuration then it must spread out (but it's more technical than that, and so are the definitions of entropy and temperature, which are also related to this. The second law is why high temp things give heat to low temp things).

Every object that is not at absolute zero radiates energy. (In the electromagnetic spectrum). Everything that follows is about reaching thermodynamic equilibrium. That's it in a nutshell. See: Black body radiation.

I know that there are radiation, i know that everything is trying to reach equilibrium... my stupid question is... why? an object has a higher energy state.... why does it "feels" the need that it need to be equalized, it needs to give off if surrounded with lower energy states? Am i making any sense? xD

fatherdoctor Yes, you're kinda making sense. As far as i understand it, everything that contains thermal energy, i.e. T=/= 0K emits energy in the form of EM-radiation. (Here is where I start speculating, because i'm not a physicist:) Why exactly this happens, has something to do with particle excitation and vibration, more or less. Since particles in higher energy states emit more energy than those in lower states it tends to equalize out over time. Unless you add energy from somewhere else.  Again, in a nutshell, from a layman. If i'm talking nonsense here someone with a deeper understanding please jump in and correct me.

The basic principle is that there are a finite number of ways to arrange things in an "orderly" way, and an infinte number of ways to just toss them together. That means that just based on probability, the state of a system will always tend towards disorder. Equilibrium (when things are as mixed together as they can be) is a much less orderly state than when hot and cold are cleanly divided.

Rhaegar19 answered your first question well. You'll notice that people are talking about the second law the thermodynamics and entropy. Both these things are the exact mathematical definition of what  Rhaegar19  is describing. Energy flows from where it is higher, towards where it is lower because it is the most probable configuration. This becomes clear when you work out the statistical behavior of a large number of atoms. To get an every day statistical example to help wrap your head around it consider two dice. The sum of two dice being rolled has different probabilities 2 and 12 have the lowest while 7 has the highest.  If you've ever played Settlers of Catan you'll have seen this first hand, or you could look at this image to see why 7 is the most probable https://bestcase.files.wordpress.com/2011/01/dicediagram.jpg. When you look at this image you'll see 7 is the most probable because there is more ways to make 7 then any other number. Now if you were to roll 2 dice a million times you would find that 7 was rolled far more often then say 12. Heat flowing from hot to cold can be thought of as a million dice rolls. There are say a million atoms. Sometimes a atom does transfer energy from cold to hot, that's a roll of 12. However most atoms will transfer energy from hot to cold, that is a roll of 7.  This is why heat flow from hot to cold, there are more ways for this to happen then the other way around when you look at it on the atomic level.

But clothes kind of do stop radiation, at least out of the human+clothes system. Any radiation from the body goes into heating the the clothes, this heat then needs to be conducted through the clothes, which have low conductivity, before being reradiated. Then there is the heat lost by evaporation. Clothes tend to trap a humid layer next to the skin lowering the evaporation rate due to the increased partial pressure of the water vapor.
The real reason for wearing clothes is social convention.  In warm climates, it is not really necessary.

There is. The name is of German (Austrian) origin, and st- is pronounced sht- in German.
varana312 I thought that scientist was from east europe, they "slovakized" the name to pure "s".

Even though he was from a Slovenian family, he was born in Austria-Hungary and worked in Vienna, so I'd guess his name was usually pronounced the "German" way. Also, the modern Slovenian writing conventions didn't take hold until the 1840s, and the spelling of names is usually very conservative. Be that as it may, even the Slovenian Wikipedia says about the pronunciation of his name [jóžef štéfan] (nepravilno [stéfan]), "nepravilno" meaning "wrongly". There is some debate about this but generally more into the direction of whether he shouldn't rather be written "Štefan" (i.e. the pronunciation as st- seems to come from the fact that he didn't write št-, not the other way around). It depends on the quantum energy levels of the substance in question. Every material has a set (not a range) of specific wavelengths it can "deal in". On the atomic/molecular level there are many different ways for matter to store the energy it absorbs, and each of these corresponds to one "slot". Low-energy waves like radio waves typically don't have the energy to fill a "slot" and so pass through or get reflected. The slots created by many molecular bonds happen to fall in the infrared/microwave range. If something gets really hot though, it starts using electron states to store energy too, and they give off visible and UV light when they fall out of their slots. Energy can even be stored in the nucleus, but it takes even higher energy to fill those slots, like gamma rays.

Microwaves specifically put their energy in the slot made by the water molecule's H-O bond. The wavelength of the waves is adjusted precisely so that the photons are just the right energy level to fit in that slot. The interiors of microwave ovens are then made in multiples of that wavelength to create a standing wave inside.

+angeldude101 how many countries say aluminum?
The man who discovered it originally called it aluminum. Also, American English is closer to classical English than modern British English is.

A British political-literary journal, in a review of Davy's book, objected to aluminum and proposed the name aluminium, "for so we shall take the liberty of writing the word, in preference to aluminum, which has a less classical sound."  The -ium suffix followed the precedent set in other newly discovered elements of the time: potassium, sodium, magnesium, calcium, and strontium (all of which Davy isolated himself). Nevertheless, element names ending in -um were not unknown at the time; for example, platinum (known to Europeans since the 16th century), molybdenum (discovered in 1778), and tantalum (discovered in 1802). The -um suffix is consistent with the universal spelling alumina for the oxide (as opposed to aluminia), as lanthana is the oxide of lanthanum, and magnesia, ceria, and thoria are the oxides of magnesium, cerium, and thorium respectively.

Yes, though perhaps not entirely in the way you think.  The two obvious ways are: 1. Reducing convective heat loss the way Dr Somara explained.  2. Reflecting some of your radiated infrared back at you.  The third is less obvious.  As the blanket warms up from being close to you, it also radiates heat away as infrared energy, but remember the emissivity constant Dr Somara introduced?  Shiny metal surfaces happen to have very low emissivity constants.  That means less of your precious heat radiates away.

Interesting. I found out the shininess is part of the emissivity constant  ε(black) = 1 and ε(mirror) = 0. If I understand this correctly a mirror dose not radiate any heat no matter it#s size because a zero in the formula makes everthing zero.

+Christoph G.   Real mirrors do not have α = 0, but they are low.  No known substance has α=1, but some are fairly high.  You might be interested to know that white surfaces, including white house paint often have rather high α.

+Mark Holm   I need to be more precise about the emissivity of white surfaces.  They have high emissivity in the infrared, not at visible wavelengths.  Emissivity of materials varies through the spectrum.   Emissivity and absorptivity are interrelated. Read the Wikipedia article.
